name: tekende
text: What do you mean "mercifully brief"? Oasis are still together. They are still making music. I don't call 16 years "brief".

name: kaithekender
text: The Oasis storyline catachresis is referring to is the one in this strip, not the band's career, which has been agonisinglylong.

name: tekende
text: Ah, I guess that would make sense.

name: lucid
text: Though it is now over. Party time?

name: shirt145
text: Yeah okay that song does blow. But there are so many rad ones. Gas Panic is superb . Supersonic, Morning Glory ... great frigging songs. Their lyrics are hells of lame, but the music and ridiculous rockstar foibles make up for it.

name: madnes
text: A comment left by madnes was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by silver_lake, Jesler729, 7th_shot, gothfae, chochacho, scrumpton, equinn2006, Aaron_Haynes, mustconcentrate, cdl146, nipsy43, lateadopter, werthog42, Wite_Rabit, stormagnet)

name: scrumpton
text: I'm guessing you've never been to Manchester then?

name: songbirdspectre
text: I am from Manchester. Dang it, Chris. You are a silly bastard.

name: pubdoggy
text: I, too, am from Manchester. I think he's done a pretty good job.

name: mattbeetee
text: Me too, but I think he is over-doing it slightly. I mean, no disrespect to him, for an American to notice these traits is fairly awesome. However - a manc would never say a 'tin of beer', for example. It's a can, just like in the US. I've never heard a northerner say 'pukka' either, I think that is more of a southern phrase but it may be just the people I hang out with. I think the most mancunian line that he managed was 'well not lately but like in the main, you know.' Straight out of Liam's mouth, in my opinion, while swaggering like a penguin in a heavy breeze.

name: laserblade
text: As an American, honestly?  I just saw these ridiculous, stylized English accents and laughed.  I didn't even know Oasis was from Manchester, I'm not familiar with any of these northern/southern nuances, I just found the cadence funny.  People who talk about the accuracy of the accents are missing the point.  They're hyperreal, like Roast Beef's dialogue  Nobody talks like them and everybody talks like them.

name: belgand
text: Though not entirely and consistently accurate the predominant stereotypes of Northerners and Southerners are reversed between the USA and England: rural area with distinctively thick accents vs. urbanized area with posh elitists.

name: dj_douche
text: A comment left by dj_douche was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by daidai, fattypneumonia, nipsy43, theplaidknight, usversusthem, Cagliostro, shirt145)

name: aliiis
text: Do they not ever say 'tinny' (a tinny of bevvy) in Manc? This may well be the case, but it is sooo Geordie, so not really that far off...

name: sex_bicycle

text: Even if it's not a great Manc accent, I was laughing for quite a while at "Obviously that were like wrong of us yeah".

name: shogun
text: The tiger doesn't like Oasis, but he still brings them beer. That's classy.  Let it never be said that Lyle is not a good host.

name: godfatherofsouls
text: It is this quality, this control that separates the Lyles from the Todds.

name: fattypneumonia
text: See, <i>this<i> is why we can't have nice things...

name: farqussus
text: HA!

name: echidnaboy
text: I have mixed feelings on this one. I'm no fan of Oasis, but Onstad's mangling of the Mancunian accent and dialect ("pukka"?!) makes me feel strangely protective toward them. On the other hand, the idea that their attempt to conquer America went so badly that they ended up working for beer in a stuffed tiger's yard fills me with the warm, fuzzy glow of schadenfreude.

name: soticoto
text:
I'm hearin you on that one.
I like suffering as much as the next guy, but when I encounter someone totally BOTCHING a p!ss-take it leaves a truly bitter taste in the mouth... especially when the target is something rather closer to home than the attacker.

name: deimosrising
text: did you just censor yourself instead of typing piss

name: soticoto
text:
Nope; I censor-bypassed... despite there being no censor.

When you've been as many places on the Internet with word-censorship as I have... and had to bypass those censors as often as I have (and I've only been banned once for it).... you might start spelling the words in censor-bypass form by default too.

name: flazisismuss
text: That's an accent?!  Wow, I just thought they had speech impediments or were playing some elaborate joke on the English language.  How come Morrissey sounds normal even though he's from Manchester, too?

name: stormagnet
text: Hard work.

name: kickstart
text: Or, as Boston comic Mike Birbiglia put it, "I don't have an accent because I'm wicked smaht

name: saulbellow
text:
I absolutely hate it when people talk about their accents, particularly when they don't seem to actually have an accent.

My least favorite thing of all time is someone telling me how their accent "comes out" when they go back home (to the South, Northeast, England, etc.) -- and yes, I have heard people from all those places say something along those lines and yes it is very very annoying thank you.

name: tekende
text: Different lifestyles, mostly.

name: drago25
text: It's def all the not eating meat.

name: sex_bicycle
text: different areas have different accents they are from manchester inner city but people from greater manchester and surrounding areas have different accents

text: a chubby to you sir, for using my favorite word :)

text:
I am from Manchester and while I know I am not personally responsible for Oasis I just want to apologise
real sorry
